segments.text: Thank you.
Thanks for joining us on another edition of Veterans of the Valley.
He grew up in Fort Worth, Texas, knowing he wanted to be a soldier.
He tried to enlist at the ripe old age of 15, even raised money to help the British fight off the Germans in World War II.
Although he graduated from Texas A&M in 1950, his military service began in 1947 when he enlisted in the U.S.
Navy Reserve.
He retired from active duty on 31 August 1982.
An end between those dates is a military career that took him to Germany.

Fort Hood, Texas, four separate times, Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, Korea, Vietnam, the Army War College in Pennsylvania, Germany, just to name a few, and finally full circle back to Texas A&M where he served as Commandant of the Corps until his retirement in 1982.
Veterans of the Valley welcomes retired Colonel James R. Woodall to today's show.
Mr. Woodall, thank you for being here.
Briefly, give us a rundown of your military career once you left A&M.
Well, when I graduated from A&M, I had a regular army commission, but I wasn't 21.
So I had to had to wait a couple of months before I went in and I went to Fort Hood and then to Germany with the second armored division.
And from Germany, I came back to Fort Hood, the fourth armored division, and then I got out of the army for a while.
and decided to go back in and finally got back in in 1960.
Fort Benning, 2nd Infantry Division, then to Korea, the 1st Cav Division up on the DMZ.
You were there for about a year, right?
I was 13 months.
And then back to the States, 2nd Armored Division at Fort Hood again.
then to Leavenworth, Kansas, Washington, D.C.
And I finally got out of Washington, D.C.
after two years and went to Vietnam where I was in the 1st Battalion of the 50th Infantry.
It was a mechanized battalion attached to the 173rd Airborne.
I was executive officer for five months and then I was a battalion commander for six months, a little over six months.
There was a battalion commander relieved in the 173rd Airborne, and so the general sent me over to this other battalion.
You actually thought you were going to get to come home a little early.
Yeah, I was getting ready to come home.
I was packing to come home.
So I went over to the Airborne Battalion for a while, and finally someone came in from the States, an Airborne Lieutenant Colonel, and took over the battalion.
So I came back to the States and came back to Fort Hood again.
And from Fort Hood, I went to Army War College and from there over to Germany and stayed in Germany for five years.
And I kept extending in Germany because Tom Parsons, the commandant here at A&M, kept extending.
And I wanted the job, so he would extend, so I would extend, and he'd extend, and I'd extend.
If you had to extend, at least you were in Germany.
Well, that's right.
That's a nice place to be.
So I stayed there five years and finally got the assignment as Commandant of Cadets.
and came back and I spent five years.
Actually, I was the professor of military science, the PMS.
And at that time, the ranking army officer was the commandant of cadets.
So that's how I got to be.
So I wore two hats, actually.
Right.
And then I retired.
And then you retired after all that.
Let's back up to Korea, I guess, is when you really saw your first action as a soldier.
Some people call it a baptism of fire.
To me, it's more like a sprinkle.
But we had some action against the North Koreans on the DMZ, and they'd come across.
We'd usually have three or four firefights a month.
What year was this?
This was in 1962 and 63.
So they'd come across the DMZ, and we'd have ambushes, and we'd try to ambush them.
They ambushed one of our trucks and they killed, I can't remember, three or four people from the ninth cab, which was actually operated in the DMZ.
We operated just south of the DMZ.
So we put out some pretty strong ambushes every night, a number of ambushes.
And the ambush I was leading one night, but we got contact with the North Koreans.
Was that a regular type thing or was it pretty much a hit and miss as far as when you would go out at night?
Did you have good, solid,

evidence that they were there was it just let's go out and see if we can dig them up they were always there they were always there and of course one thing we were trying to do is is prevent line crossers because there were spies going north and south all the time trying to catch those people uh but uh there was a lot of activity about a 10-day period uh we had we had some pretty good firefights along the dmz any any any particular firefight that you really remember that sticks out
Well, the one that I was the patrol leader on.
Of course, I wasn't supposed to be out there because I was the battle group S-1, you know.
I was a rear echelon guy.
Well, how did you end up at the front?
Well, I just volunteered.
And I got me a, put together a patrol and took them out.
I think there were about 12 of us, but it was a nice little action.
I had one man that got hit, but I think he was hit with our own grenade, you know.
We were throwing grenades a little bit.
And he got hit in the face and I pulled the thing out of his face and told me he's all right.
Slapped the bandage on it.
And you went on your way.
Continued on.
Anything else about Korea that really stands out?
Well, it was a very long tour.
It seemed like it was years, but and it was it was kind of a depressing place to serve.
What was the weather like there?
Well, it was hot in the summer and in the winter it was so cold.
It was really miserable in the winter.
What was the average day like?
Did you go out on patrol every single day or would there be a, you know, a stand down day type thing?
Well, I didn't go out on patrol except when I volunteered because I was pushing papers in the headquarters.
But we had one company each night that was on, we call it stakeout, ambush patrols along the DMZ.
And the rest of the time, the units were just training.
Mm-hmm.
Okay, so after Korea, where to?
Well, I came back to Fort Hood.
You came back to Fort Hood again, and what duties did you handle there at Fort Hood?
I was the assistant G1 in the division headquarters of the 2nd Armory Division.
And I got back, and I was immediately told that the 2nd Armory Division would go into Germany for a maneuver.
They call it Operation Big Lift.
So my wife was not too happy with it.
I just unpacked my bags and I said, hey, I got to pack again because I'm gone.
And so a few weeks after I got back to Korea, I was in Germany and we went over there and stayed about a month or six weeks.
Okay.
What was that like?
What part of Germany was that in?
Well, that was along the Rhine River and then in the what they call the Oldenbaal, which is near Heidelberg up in the mountains there.
And it was the area where I had maneuvered in when I was over there the first time, so I knew all the... You already knew pretty much the area.
I knew the terrain, yeah.
Okay.
I was glad to get back to Germany after.
And all I could say is somebody sold a lot of automobiles since 1954 when I left.
Okay, let's talk about Vietnam.
When did you first find out that you were going to be going to Vietnam?
Well...
I kept thinking I was going to Vietnam, but they kept assigning me somewhere else.

And then finally, when I got to Washington, D.C., they said I had to stay there two years because I thought out of the Commandant General Staff College, surely I would go to Vietnam, but I was sent to Washington.
So after I got up there, I checked with the personnel of people, and they said, no, you've got to stay here two years.
So I said, okay, I want to go in the summer of 1968, mid-summer 1968, and I'm going to go to the 1st Cav Division.
Right.
And that almost worked out for you, or you thought it was working out?
Well, I got my orders.
July 15th, 1st Cav Division.
That's exactly what I wanted.
And when I got to Cam'ron Bay in Vietnam, they said, check the bulletin board every day and see your assignment.
Well, I thought, you know, why?
I've got an assignment.
I don't need to check the bulletin board.
You knew where you were going, right?
But I checked the bulletin board anyway.
And after about two or three days, it said 173rd Airborne.
It was a shock to me.
I was airborne qualified, but I really wanted to be in the first cab.
So I reported up to the 173rd Airborne Brigade Headquarters and spent the night there.
And the first night, somebody started shooting at us, and I thought, I think I'm in the war now.
The next day, I flew down on a helicopter.
The battalion commander picked me up on his helicopter, flew me down to, they call it LZ Uplift, which was just a big dome area, no grass.
It was all red dirt, surrounded by mountains, and you could see smoke coming up all over the place.
Explain what LZ is.
A landing zone.
A landing zone.
It was a base camp, is what it was.
So I flew in there, and I thought, that looks just like Din Ben Poo.
or what I knew of Dinh Binh Phu, where the French were defeated in Vietnam.
Right.
And I knew it wasn't Dinh Binh Phu, but I thought it was weird because hills all around and everything.
So I landed.
I looked up, and the first thing I saw was there was a tent with a French flag.
My goodness.
I thought, well, I'm in the twilight zone.
But it turned out to be an Iowa state flag, and that's just a reverse of a French flag.
So I was glad to know that I wasn't in the twilight zone.
But I was the battalion executive officer in the battalion, the first of the 50th.
We were on the coast of the South China Sea.
We call it the Bansang Plains.
And the enemy in that area was mostly VCs.
Viet Cong.
Viet Cong.
And I'd been there about two months when we were ordered to go back, or not to go back, but to be transferred to the Central Highlands near An Cay, Camp Radcliffe.
And our primary mission there was securing the highway.
That was the first mission.
The second mission was to conduct operations in the local area.
And we had the highway between An Cay Pass and the Manyang Pass, Highway 19.
And we had to keep two companies on the highway.
We had two fire bases.
And we put out strong points every day.
There were a number of bridges.
We had to guard the bridges.
And then we always had one company operating off the highway out in the boonies.
We normally had a Mike strike force attached to us.
That's a Montagnard soldiers commanded by special forces.
A lot of the viewers may not know what the Montagnards are.
Okay, the Montagnards were the hill tribes of... They were more or less the indigenous peoples.
The indigenous peoples.
They were the Indians of Vietnam.
Okay.
But they were fairly primitive people, but a beautiful people.
And did you find them to be a really big help to to your endeavors?
Well, you know, having an extra battalion attached to you was a big help.
And we we were their purpose was to keep the N.V.A.
off guard so they wouldn't come up and and strike the highway.
Mm hmm.
So they they served their purpose.
They did.
Did you did the American forces get along with them?
Oh, yeah.
Well, they were.
Well, you know, they'd come in and
spend the night, then they'd go out in the field and stay 30 days.
So we wouldn't see them.
Well, I'd see them because I'd go out every once in a while and visit.
But they were.
They would literally go out for 30 days and literally live off the land there in the jungle.
That's right.
Yeah.
So we had one, well, actually two incidents with the Montagnards that were pretty sad.
Tiger got into one of their night perimeters and grabbed one of the guys and drug him off in the jungle.
And the next morning they found him half eaten.
And in the same area the next month, same thing happened.
Tiger got in, grabbed one of these mountain yards.
You know, the little people, 100 pounds or so, 90, but very small.
And so we lost two soldiers that way.
Now, our soldiers were pretty spooky.
They got kind of spooked after hearing that story.
So the people were alert at night.
And about two months later, after these incidents, the Montagnards, the local Montagnard people living in the Montagnard villages, they came out of the jungle carrying a tiger.
And we were convinced that that was the, we called him the man-eater of Anke.
We were convinced that they'd killed the man-eater of Anke.
And the story I was told, that the Montagnards killed him with a crossbow.
Mm-hmm.
And just a few months ago, I was contacting one of my former company commanders about that story.
And he said, no, they didn't kill him with the crossbow.
They poisoned him.
He said, I know because I tried to buy the skin.
They wanted $500 for it.
And I was about to pay it.
But then I decided, well, what am I going to do with tiger skin?
How am I going to get it treated properly?
And how am I going to get it back to the state?
So he passed that up.
They did kill the man-eater.
So that was great.
What was the other... Did you have another Montagnard story?
I think you said there were two of them.
No, there were two people eaten by a tiger.
Okay.
What were some other events that you can remember that happened there?
Well, one of the... In Camp Radcliffe, it was a very large camp.
It used to be the base camp of the first camp.
Tremendous...
and not too many people in there.
Right at one edge of it, there was this tall Sugarloaf Mountain.
It was called Hong Kong Mountain.
And we had a signal installation up on top of this thing.
I don't know how, a thousand feet or something.
And we had snipers.
The entire time I was there, we had snipers on that mountain shooting down into the, there was a hospital there.
They shoot into the hospital and they shoot into supply areas and things like that.
And we never did.
I put, in fact, I put a Montagnard battalion, one of those Mike's strike forces, up there for three days trying to catch those snipers.
And we never did get them.
I thought that was pretty weird.
We got people inside the wire, you know, permanently.
I guess the...
The thing I remember most was on February the 14th, Valentine's Day, we had a big ambush, and it was in an area where we hadn't had an ambush before.
They always hit us to the west of Anke, but we never did have anything go on to the east, and they pulled off a major ambush on a convoy.
And we only had a bridge out there.
Very few of our troops were there.
We had two bridges, I think.
We just had enough people to guard the bridge, but we had no regular forces out there.
So they hit the convoy pretty hard, and that was really one of the actions I got deeply involved in because I just happened to be in my Jeep leaving the gate of Camp Radcliffe.
I normally would fly in my helicopter.
I had a Charlie Charlie command and control helicopter every day.
I would normally fly in that, but that day, for some reason, I decided, well, I'm going to go in my Jeep.
It was a nice day, so you decided to stay on the ground.

Drive up and down the highway, and just as I left the gate, I heard the explosions, and then on the radio, they said this convoy had been hit, so I dashed out there, and immediately I started getting the trucks that were not in the actual kill zone, making those guys move out and clear the area, and then
spotted some NVA, and I got my driver, my artillery officer, and we went over and we assaulted these NVA, and after that, and we eliminated them.
Did you have any idea what kind of force you were up against at that time?
Well, we figured it was probably at least a company of North Vietnamese.
And a company would be how many?
Well, the North Vietnamese, it might be 60, 75, because they're usually under strength.
helped eliminate a lot of them.
But anyway, after that was over, my driver told me, he said, sir, you're going to get me killed.
I said, no, Johnson, I'm going to send you home a hero.
And I did.
He was getting pretty sharp then, but I sent him home.

made it all right but he he didn't really care for that uh little escapade okay i'm sorry go ahead and you didn't you end up sending your uh your xo or so forth back to the to the rear well in this that day they hit us on the other other side there was another ambush another contact on the other to the west of this is that the first time that it ever happened you know before usually we'd have we'd have a contact and that would be it that would be it but they hit us here with a major ambush then they hit us
at the other end of the area of operations.
Trying to do an end-to-round on you, more or less.

So I told my executive officer after that, I said, anytime we get a contact, if it's in the west, you're just going out to the eastern part of the sector, or if it's in the east, you go to the west, and then you can just assume command of that area, because we're talking about a
20 mile, 20 mile stretch there.
As far as a convoy would be stretched out.
Well, no, the road.
I mean, we're talking about trying to protect 20 miles of road or 25.
That's a lot of road.
It is.
Okay, anything else?
We've got a few things here on the table that you mentioned the Montagnards and the bow with the tiger.
And obviously this is not the bow, but this is one that you brought back.
Yeah, this is what I thought killed the tiger.
Now I should have known better.
This is the quiver and you can see this is made out of bamboo, these arrows.
And all of these were obviously hand-fashioned and handmade.
Oh, yeah.
And this is really some fine work if you'll look at it.
And it's got the little trigger there.
And this is pulled back and placed in there.
And the arrow there.
Did you ever get a chance to see them use one of these, even if it was just for practicing to see how accurate they were?
No, I tried to use it.
But, you know, it's so hard to pull this back.
But I did shoot this.
But the mine yard would just stick it in their stomach and pull it back.
And here's another interesting piece that you brought with you.
Well, this is a North Vietnamese, we call them hard hats.
And the North Vietnamese regulars, the NVA would, a lot of times, they would be wearing hard hats.
Kind of like our helmet, except it's really not a... It wouldn't protect much.
It's a sun helmet, what it is, actually, rather than a... Keep the shade off your head, and that's about all it would be good for.
So we picked up a lot of those.
We've also, you also were kind enough to give us about 15 or 16 pictures we can pull up here and have some pretty interesting pictures here.
Explain this to us because... Well, that's about, whenever the Battle of the Britain, the Battle of Britain went on 1940, I don't know if it's 40 or 41, probably 1940.
That's you on the left, right?
That's me on the left.
I've been a collector of stuff all my life, and that was one of my first collections there was that aerial bomb.
I think it's a practice bomb.
I bought it in a junkyard, and I had that.
So this is my good buddy Joe Earl Hodgkins on the right there.
He was my running mate, partner in crime and so forth.
And this was up at Lake Worth.
And this was out at Lake Worth at my grandfather's store, J.R.
Foster Ice and Feed store.
So I decided, well, I was going to help the British, so I put this up, collected money, and then took it down to the, I think it was the British Aid Society and turned it into them.
So I'm trying to do my bit.
And that was my freshman year.
That's a strapping young man right there.
Freshman year, just turned 17 when I entered A&M.
I've been here a while because you can see I was pretty underweight.
They already worked you somehow.
That's right, yeah.
And that's the senior ring dance.
Now, there's an interesting story behind this.
Well, this particular picture with you, the former students had that picture over there for a little article they put in the Texas Aggie some time ago.
And then my granddaughter graduated here last year and she went over to get a ring and they gave her a brochure about the Aggie ring and so forth.
And she opened it up and recognized our picture.
They had used our picture.
My goodness.
Without authority.
Did you contact them and talk residuals?
Well, maybe I should.
It's a great picture.
Now this... Okay, those are the survivors of Company D infantry.
We started out with about 38 and we wound up with, this is just before graduation, with eight.
And you'll notice the guy in the uniform there on the back row, that's Jarvis Miller, former president.
So at one time, the class of 50 had the president
and Commandant of Cadets.
You didn't know it then, but you were both right there.
That's right.
And that's, I was about 17, and that's when I joined the Navy Reserve and
That was in Pat O'Brien's in New Orleans.
And I'll tell you that's a Pat O'Brien's hurricane sitting there.
It's a hurricane punch, I think they call it.
And your pack of Lucky Strikes.
I was smoking in those days, and there's a pack of Lucky Strikes.
And Lucky Strike had gone to war, see that white pack.
Exactly.
And that's me when I was a lieutenant in the 2nd Armored Division.
I was in the 41st Armored Infantry Battalion, a platoon leader.
In fact, I commanded the same platoon for almost four years.
There was only one place to go that was up.
That's the An K marketplace that my battalion, the civil affairs people built for the Vietnamese, and that's the district chief there.
I doubt if he made it.
And that's General Barnes, the commander of 173rd Airborne, and that's when they presented me with a Silver Star.
And you were presented to Silver Star due to that battle there on February 14th of 69th.
St.
Valentine's Day Massacre.
Right, exactly.
And that's me just...
popping a few caps, you know, shooting.
This is on February the 14th, but the enemy, they were withdrawing.
I thought, well, I'll just send them a little souvenir.
Make sure they've left.
And one thing you notice about this picture, everybody's hunched over.
And that's, well, I call it the combat crouch.
Because you think you're making yourself a smaller target.
That's Captain Cheney, who's the company commander of the reaction force that joined us in that battle.
And on the right, the popular forces
that came out to help, and that's me in the center.
And if you look in the back, I don't know if you can see it or not, but you can see the trucks and the smoke and all that.
I've already moved all the trucks out of this area, but we're getting ready to make another sweep.
That's one of my personnel carriers.
We need to move on here if I can get Sandra to come on back because we've only got three minutes left, believe it or not.
And something else I want to show the people here is, like I said in the open, you have a lot of medals that you were awarded.
And this is just the shadow blocks that you were kind enough to bring.
And the folks can see the plethora of awards.
And as we get to the top here, you can tell us what those three right there in the middle are.
Well, there's a silver star.
That's the one with the red, white, and blue ribbon.
And in the middle is the Legion of Merit.
And then the other one is the Bronze Star.
Right.
And that's kind of my career in that one case with the battalions and the regiments I was in.
We've only got a couple minutes left, believe it or not.
And you said you wanted to talk just a brief minute about the Corps.
Well, that was the greatest job I ever had.
was common on the Corps.
I'm really concerned about the size of the Corps and about the difficulty we're having in recruiting people to come in the Corps.
I will never understand why some of them would come down to A&M and not want to be in the Corps of Cadets.
You get so much.
You get a mental toughness.
learn to operate under stress.
There's so many advantages.
They're not getting their money's worth if they're not in the Corps of Cadets.
And if you think about it, if we didn't have the Corps of Cadets, what would we have?
We would have a campus dominated, the dominant force would be fraternities and sororities.
And so we might as well call it University of Texas at College Station because it would soon be just like university over there if it wasn't for the Corps of Cadets.
I agree with you wholeheartedly, and I'm sure quite a few other people on Talwood, too.
I'll probably get some flack about that, but you know I've had flack before.
You've been around it.
I think you can weather it.
That's right.
We're out of time totally.
I would like to thank you so much for being here.
It was a pleasure.
Thank you.
You know, Colonel Woodall served his country with pride, honor, and distinction.
He had a military career that lasted over 35 years.
He's been awarded so many medals that we couldn't mention them all.

He had the Silver Star, the Legion of Merit with Oak Leaf Cluster, the Bronze Star with Valor Device and two Oak Leaf Clusters, the Meritorious Service Medal with Oak Leaf Cluster, and the Air Medal with seven Oak Leaf Clusters.
The list goes on and on.
Veterans of the Valley salutes Colonel James Woodall for his unwavering dedication and commitment to serving the country he loves.
For Colonel Woodall, the entire KMU staff, and Tom Turbyville, I'm Kyle Netterville saying thank you for watching.
So long for now until the next Roll Call for Veterans of the Valley.
you
